title: 104_s2115
content:
The "Sportsmen's Bill of Rights Act of 1996" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings and policy statements. Congress finds that fishing and hunting are important traditional recreational activities in which millions of Americans participate. Survey data shows strong support for the legality of fishing and hunting, with anglers and hunters being key supporters of wildlife management and conservation practices in the United States. (5) Hunters and fishermen, along with related organizations, assist wildlife managers and enforcement officers at various government levels.
(6) Revenue from licenses, permits, stamps, and excise taxes on angling and hunting goods has generated over $6 billion for wildlife research and management.
(7) Fishing and hunting play a crucial role in wildlife management by reducing conflicts between humans and wildlife, and incentivizing conservation of habitats and ecosystems. Federal agency must support fishing and hunting opportunities. Federal agency must support fishing and hunting opportunities on federal lands. Federal land is generally open for fishing and hunting, unless restricted by the State or Federal agency for wildlife management, national security, or specific statutory requirements. There is no priority given to fishing or hunting over other land uses or management priorities. The Act does not diminish State authority in regulating fish and wildlife on State and Federal land. Federal agency authority over fish and wildlife on Federal land is limited to that of a private landowner, unless specified by Congress. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF THE INTEGRITY OF THE SPORTSMEN'S TRUST ACCOUNTS. The Federal Aid in Wildlife Restoration Act is amended to change the responsible Secretary to the Secretary of the Interior and restrict the use of funding for other expenses under the Secretary's authority. The Federal Aid in Fish Restoration Act is amended to restrict funding for other expenses under the Secretary of the Interior's authority. SEC. 5. EVALUATION OF WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT EFFECTS. Federal agency actions that may impact fishing or hunting on Federal land must be evaluated before implementation. Notice and public hearings are required before taking such actions. Individuals affected by loss of fishing or hunting opportunities can seek judicial review in court. In United States district court, civil actions can be taken to review agency actions. Agencies can close Federal lands in emergencies. This section does not apply to the Migratory Bird Treaty Act or the Magnuson Fishery Conservation and Management Act. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATIONS RELATING TO MAINTENANCE OF FISHING AND HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES. Definition of Point Source under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to exclude agricultural stormwater discharges and return flows from irrigated agriculture. It also includes any conveyance directly assisting individuals. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to exclude agricultural stormwater discharges and return flows from irrigated agriculture. It now includes dredged or fill material resulting from fishing, hunting, or recreational shooting activities. Federal agencies must promote fishing and hunting by enhancing existing programs and establishing new ones under the Federal Aid in Wildlife Restoration Act and the Federal Aid in Fish Restoration Act. Civil actions are also addressed. SEC. 8. CIVIL ACTIONS. A person interested in fishing or hunting has the right to intervene in civil actions related to the use of Federal land that may impact access for fishing or hunting. The court must consider the impact on fishing and hunting access before granting relief under another Federal law. SEC. 9. STANDING TO BRING A CIVIL ACTION. A licensed angler, licensed hunter, or organization representing the interests of licensed anglers or hunters may bring a civil action in a United States district court to seek relief regarding the implementation of this Act, including preventing actions that may disrupt fishing or hunting opportunities.
